docs.lead_paragraph: ALMOST a thousand years ago, a teacher fell in love with his student. Almost a thousand years ago, they began a torrid affair. They made love in the kitchens of convents and in the boudoir of the girl's uncle. They wrote hundreds of love letters. When the girl bore a child, they were secretly married, but the teacher was castrated by henchmen of the enraged uncle. At her lover's bidding, the girl took religious orders. He took the habit of a monk. They retreated into separate monasteries and wrote to each other until parted by death. The story of Abelard and Heloise hardly resonates with the spirit of our age. Not least, its origins in the classroom offend: teachers, we know, are not supposed to fall in love with their students. Heloise, moreover, is no feminist heroine, despite having been one of the best educated women of her age and writing some of its most affecting prose. Nobody who takes the veil on the command of her husband and swears ''complete obedience'' to him can hope to sneak into the bastion of feminism. Today, even the high romance of the couple's liaison strikes us as foreign: all that sacrifice and intensity! We live in a time of broad antiromanticism when teenagers, according to The Times Magazine, have given up on relationships altogether and adults write to the editor to salute their wisdom. ''Romance?'' scoffed one correspondent. It's just ''an excuse . . . to work off sexual energy.''
docs.abstract: Cristina Nehring essay on new books addressing and inspired by the myth of Abelard and Heloise discusses books Heloise and Abelard by James Burge, Farewell, My Only One by Antoine Audouard, Abelard and Heloise by Constant J Mews, The Letters of Abelard and Heloise translated with an introduction and notes by Betty Radice, and The Lost Letters of Heloise and Abelard: Perceptions of Dialogue in Twelfth-Century France by Contstant J Mews; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: A flurry of new writing on the two ill-fated 12th-century lovers suggests a longing to recover the grandeur of high-stakes romance.

docs.lead_paragraph: ANNMARIE HURLEY still remembers a conversation more than 13 years ago with her boss, Dr. Fred Danziger, as if it were yesterday. Dr. Danziger, a dentist in Long Beach, N.Y., asked Ms. Hurley, then a 26-year-old dental hygienist, if she had ever thought about disability insurance. She had not, but after listening to him and meeting with his insurance agent, she decided that the policy made sense. Three years later, when she developed pronator teres syndrome, a painful nerve problem, in one arm and carpal tunnel syndrome in both hands and was no longer able to do her job, the policy premium of $519 a year seemed like the best money she had ever spent. But in 1997, after a year and a half of collecting $2,250 a month in benefits, the insurer, First Unum, stopped paying, even though Ms. Hurley's contract provided for lifetime benefits. For eight years, Ms. Hurley, with the help of a lawyer, has been fighting the company, now called UnumProvident, to have benefits reinstated. So far, she hasn't had much luck.
docs.abstract: Scrutiny of business practices of UnumProvident, nation's largest provider of disability insurance, makes many people cautious about disability insurance in general; experts offer advice on what to look for in a policy and how to shop for one; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Anyone who does not have an investment portfolio large enough to cover monthly expenses should probably consider disability insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: Will the war of words between Craig Carton and acting Gov. Richard J. Codey ever end? It has been three weeks since Mr. Carton, co-host of ''The Jersey Guys'' on WKXW-FM (101.5), offered a flip prescription for the governor's wife, who suffers from depression, over the airwaves. Mr. Codey, who happened to be at the station for his own broadcast, retaliated by -- depending on whom you ask -- telling Mr. Carton that he would either like to ''take him out'' or ''take him outside.''

headline.main: Codey's Radio Wars: Yet Another Round

docs.abstract: New Jersey Assemblyman Wilfredo Caraballo, sponsor of measure to censure WKXW-FM co-host Craig Carton, comments on feud over post-partum depression between Carton and Acting Gov Richard Codey (S)
docs.snippet: Will the war of words between Craig Carton and acting Gov. Richard J. Codey ever end?    It has been three weeks since Mr. Carton, co-host of ''The Jersey Guys'' on WKXW-FM (101.5), offered a flip prescription for the governor's wife, who suffers...

docs.lead_paragraph: John Taylor, a Treasury under secretary, delivered a personal blow to the British chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, last week by putting the kibosh on Mr. Brown's ambitious proposal for cutting third-world debt. Mr. Taylor was standing in for his boss, Treasury Secretary John Snow, at the Group of 7 finance ministers meeting in London. One United Nations official joked that Mr. Snow probably caught the flu because he did not want to be the Grim Reaper at the meeting. No problem. Mr. Taylor played that role admirably. If this is Tony Blair's repayment for putting his political career on the line to support President Bush in Iraq, then Mr. Blair might want to rethink that so-called special relationship.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Treasury Under Sec John Taylor delivered personal blow to British Chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown's ambitious proposal for cutting third-world debt; holds that Prime Min Tony Blair has made it his mission to use Britain's turn in Group of 7 presidency to work on poverty in Africa and around world; holds that if this is Blair's repayment for putting his political career on line to support Pres Bush in Iraq, then Blair might want to rethink that so-called special relationship
docs.snippet: John Taylor, a Treasury under secretary, delivered a blow to the British chancellor of the exchequer at the Group of 7 meeting. Is this Tony Blair's payment for supporting President Bush in Iraq?

docs.lead_paragraph: The night lights of New York, spangled across a picture window two stories high, made a glittering, seductive backdrop to the story of money and greed that is William Bolcom and Arnold Weinstein's musical ''Casino Paradise,'' which had a concert performance in the Allen Room of Jazz at Lincoln Center on Wednesday as part of the American Songbook series. ''Casino Paradise'' is the story of a wealthy developer who buys up oceanfront property to build casinos, to the successive horror, excitement and downfall of the locals. Any resemblance to Donald Trump is purely intentional. The piece had its premiere in 1990, when interest in Mr. Trump was high; and it just had a revival at the Philadelphia theater that commissioned it, the Prince (formerly the American Music Theater Festival), possibly trying to ride the new wave of Trump-itis fostered by the success of the television reality show ''The Apprentice.''

headline.main: A Tycoon Gambles On Greed, Then Love

docs.abstract: Anne Midgette reviews William Bolcom-Arnold Weinstein musical Casino Paradise in concert performance at Jazz at Lincoln Center; photo (S)
docs.snippet: "Casino Paradise," a musical about a wealthy developer, as seen at Lincoln Center on Wednesday, has a certain naïveté and lacks a focused plot.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first time Patricia McCreary became pregnant, she had a baby. ''I look at that now as this naïve bliss time, when I thought pregnancy meant a baby,'' said Ms. McCreary, who lives in Seattle.

headline.main: Specialists Trying to Unravel The Mystery of Miscarriage

docs.abstract: Miscarriages, although common, are rarely discussed and often go unexplained despite continued increase in most types of fertility counseling and assistance; Dr Aydin M Arici, Yale School of Medicine reproductive endocrinology and infertility director, holds recurrent miscarriages, women under 40 who experience three or more miscarriages with same partner, have many causes; recent studies have focused on immune system function as possible factor; other treatment options, most of which are untested, discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Thousands of American women cannot hold on to their babies beyond the first few weeks of pregnancy  and no one can explain why.
